items.title: US, India clash over stalled trade deal

featured_image.name: India-US trade deal stalled after Modi did not call Trump ...

items.description:
A diplomatic rift has emerged between the United States and India over the reasons behind stalled trade negotiations, with Washington and New Delhi offering sharply different accounts of why a bilateral agreement remains elusive.

US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick claimed Thursday that a trade deal collapsed because Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi failed to personally telephone President Donald Trump to finalize the agreement. Speaking on the All-In Podcast, Lutnick said India was given "three Fridays" to seal the deal but proved "uncomfortable" arranging the call[1][2][3][4]. "I said — You need to have Modi; it's all arranged. Modi must call the president. Yet, they were hesitant to do it," Lutnick said. "Consequently, Modi did not make the call"[1].

India swiftly rejected the characterization. Ministry of External Affairs spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal told reporters Friday that the two leaders spoke eight times during 2025 and that both nations have been "close to a deal" on multiple occasions[1][5][6]. "The characterization of these discussions in the reported remarks is not accurate," Jaiswal said, adding that India remains "interested in a mutually beneficial trade deal"[7][2][6].

The White House has not responded to Lutnick's comments[3][8].

items.title: NASA's Pandora satellite to launch Saturday, study exoplanet atmospheres

featured_image.name: Signs of alien life could be spotted on this exoplanet 'map ...

items.description:
Astronomers are deploying new missions and refining detection methods as the hunt for extraterrestrial life enters what researchers describe as a transformative phase, with several breakthrough developments emerging this week.

NASA's Pandora satellite is scheduled to launch January 11 aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg Space Force Base, marking the first mission in the agency's Astrophysics Pioneers program dedicated specifically to studying exoplanet atmospheres[1][2]. The compact $20 million spacecraft will observe at least 20 known exoplanets during its one-year mission, searching for water vapor and other potential biosignatures by separating planetary signals from the interfering light of their host stars[1][2].

"Pandora's goal is to disentangle the atmospheric signals of planets and stars using visible and near-infrared light," said Elisa Quintana, Pandora's principal investigator at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center[2]. The mission will perform 10 observations of each target planet, with continuous 24-hour monitoring sessions designed to track how stellar surface features impact measurements[2].

items.title: Swiss, Korean teams report solid-state battery advances

featured_image.name: Solid state battery announcement - ESOX Group

items.description:
Researchers in Switzerland and South Korea have announced separate breakthroughs this week that could accelerate the commercialization of all-solid-state lithium batteries, addressing two of the technology's most persistent challenges: dendrite formation and high manufacturing costs.

On January 7, the Paul Scherrer Institute in Switzerland reported a new production process that combines gentle sintering with a thin protective coating to stabilize battery performance[1][2][3][4]. The approach achieved 75 percent capacity retention after 1,500 charge cycles, among the best results reported to date for solid-state systems[1][3]. Meanwhile, researchers at South Korea's KAIST announced a structural design breakthrough that boosted lithium ion mobility by two to four times using inexpensive materials, published in Nature Communications[5][6][7][8].

items.title: Venezuela, US launch talks to restore diplomatic ties

featured_image.name: Venezuela says in exploratory talks with US on restoring ...

items.description:
Venezuela announced Friday it has launched an "exploratory" diplomatic process with the United States aimed at restoring relations and reopening embassies that were severed in 2019, marking a significant diplomatic thaw less than a week after US forces captured President Nicolas Maduro[1][2][3][4][5][6].

US State Department officials traveled to Caracas on Friday to assess a potential phased resumption of embassy operations, while Venezuela confirmed it would send a reciprocal delegation to Washington[1][2][3][7]. The visit represents the first US diplomatic presence in Venezuela since Maduro's capture in a military operation on January 3, 2026[7][8].

items.title: X's Grok limits image generator over non-consensual sexual imagery
items.description: For more than a week, X's AI bot Grok has been generating sexual images of women and children at the request of other users, even when they ask it not to.

items.title: The rhetoric of the Trump administration has taken a chilling turn
items.description: There have been plenty of examples of the Trump administration's contempt for legalities, diplomacy and alliances but this week Trump and his lieutenants went further.

items.title: CES wraps with AI optimism, solar breakthroughs

featured_image.name: Jackery debuts trio of products at CES, including 2 surprises

items.description:
The annual Consumer Electronics Show wrapped up in Las Vegas this week with a markedly different tone than previous years, as industry leaders expressed renewed confidence about artificial intelligence while showcasing a wave of solar energy breakthroughs that extend far beyond traditional rooftop panels.

"The ChatGPT moment for physical AI is here," declared Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang during his keynote address, capturing the prevailing sentiment at CES 2026[1][2][3]. The show featured humanoid robots navigating exhibition floors, AI-powered chips reaching production at unprecedented speeds, and a pervasive sense that the technology industry had moved past last year's existential anxieties about AI's impact[4].

items.title: Greenland official wants talks with US without Denmark

featured_image.name: Greenland wants more out of US defence agreement, minister ...

items.description:
Greenland's foreign minister suggested that the Arctic territory should meet with the United States independently without Denmark present, signaling that American pressure tactics may be driving a wedge between Copenhagen and Nuuk as President Donald Trump continues to pursue his ambitions to acquire the island.

Vivian Motzfeldt told Danish broadcaster DR on Friday that Greenland should "take the lead" in discussions with Washington[1][2]. "When it comes to Greenland, it should be Greenland that takes the lead and speaks with the United States," she said[2]. "What would be wrong with us holding meetings with the United States on our own?"[1][2]

The comments come ahead of a scheduled meeting next week between US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and officials from both Denmark and Greenland, marking the first significant three-way dialogue since Trump intensified his push to gain control of the territory[1][3][4]. While Motzfeldt acknowledged that the upcoming meeting would include Denmark and that Greenland still lacks authority over its own foreign policy, her remarks underscore growing tensions over how the semi-autonomous territory should navigate US pressure[1][2].

items.title: Ukraine demands UN meeting after Russia fires Oreshnik missile near EU

featured_image.name: Russia under fire at UN security council over Ukraine strikes

items.description:
Ukraine initiated an urgent United Nations Security Council meeting on Friday following Russia's use of its advanced Oreshnik intermediate-range ballistic missile against the western Lviv region, marking only the second deployment of the hypersonic weapon in combat and escalating tensions as peace negotiations continue.

Foreign Minister Andrii Sybiha declared the strike near the European Union and NATO borders "a grave threat to the security on the European continent and a test for the transatlantic community," calling for decisive international action including meetings of the Ukraine-NATO Council and responses within the EU, Council of Europe, and OSCE[1][2][3].

items.title: Black hole shreds star in brightest explosion ever seen

featured_image.name: Super star' being shredded by black hole releases as much ...

items.description:
Astronomers have captured one of the most powerful cosmic explosions ever observed, an event that released energy equivalent to 400 billion suns as a black hole tore apart and devoured a massive star. The discovery, presented this week at the American Astronomical Society conference in Phoenix, provides unprecedented insight into how black holes feed and the extreme physics governing these violent encounters[1][2][3][4].

The event, officially designated AT2024wpp and nicknamed "the Whippet," was first detected on September 25, 2024, by the Zwicky Transient Facility at Palomar Observatory in California[5][6]. Located approximately 1.1 billion light-years from Earth, it represents the brightest example to date of a Luminous Fast Blue Optical Transient, a rare class of cosmic explosion that scientists are still working to understand[2][7][5].

"We discovered what we think is a black hole merging with a massive companion star, shredding it into a disk that feeds the black hole," said Daniel Perley, the study's lead author from Liverpool John Moores University, at the conference[1][2][3]. "This was many times more energetic than any similar event and more than any known explosion powered by the collapse of a star."

items.title: Trump cancels second Venezuela strikes after prisoner releases

featured_image.name: World leaders react to the U.S. attack on Venezuela

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Friday that he has canceled a previously expected second wave of military attacks against Venezuela, citing cooperation from the country's interim government including the release of political prisoners[1][2].

In a statement posted on his social media platform, Trump declared that "at least 100 Billion Dollars" would be invested by major oil companies in rebuilding Venezuela's oil and gas infrastructure, adding that he would meet with the executives at the White House later that day[1][2]. Despite the cancellation, Trump emphasized that "all ships will stay in place for safety and security purposes"[1][2].

The announcement came one day after Venezuela began releasing a significant number of political detainees, including prominent opposition figures Enrique Márquez, a former presidential candidate, and Biagio Pilieri, as well as security analyst Rocío San Miguel and five Spanish nationals[3][4][5]. The releases represent the first signs of cooperation since U.S. forces captured President Nicolás Maduro in a special operations raid on January 3[6][7][8].

items.title: Chinese scientists unveil lithium and sodium batteries

featured_image.name: China Lithium Battery Demand to Slow in Early 2026 | Net ...

items.description: Researchers in China have published two separate breakthroughs this week in battery technology that could reshape energy storage, introducing a sunlight-assisted lithium-sulfur battery and a high-voltage sodium-sulfur battery as alternatives to conventional lithium-ion cells.
